docs.lead_paragraph: It is a recurring question - sometimes a taunt - inside and outside Washington: Why shouldn't members of Congress be forced to use the same health insurance that its members are now designing for people who have no coverage?

headline.main: Should Rules for All Include Congress?

docs.abstract: Some are pushing for Congress to use the same health insurance that its members are now designing for people who have no coverage.
docs.snippet: Some are pushing for Congress to use the same health insurance that its members are now designing for people who have no coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care and Afghanistan have dominated the discussion in Washington recently, so it should be no big surprise that once again those topics will be front-and-center on the Sunday talk shows.
docs.abstract: Lots of health care and Afghanistan on the menu Sunday morning.
docs.snippet: Lots of health care and Afghanistan on the menu Sunday morning.

docs.lead_paragraph: During his weekly address, President Obama continued to talk up his proposals to aid small businesses -- what he called "the engine of our economy."

headline.main: The Saturday Word: Revving the Engine

docs.abstract: The president touts his small-business proposals in his weekly address, while Republicans use theirs to slam the Democrats' health care proposals.
docs.snippet: The president touts his small-business proposals in his weekly address, while Republicans use theirs to slam the Democrats' health care proposals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur Ullian is president of the National Council on Spinal Cord Injury and co-author of two studies in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences on the economics of health care. In a forthcoming analysis, Mr. Ullian, the demographer Kenneth G. Manton of Duke University, the statistician Dennis Tolley of Brigham Young University and others conclude that expanded access to health care will generate revenue and savings for the federal government that are not accounted for in official cost estimates. Mr. Ullian spoke with the freelance writer Anne Underwood.
docs.abstract: Increased tax revenues and Medicare savings resulting from healthier yet older labor force may offset the costs of a health care overhaul, according to a forthcoming analysis.
docs.snippet: Increased tax revenues and Medicare savings resulting from healthier yet older labor force may offset the costs of a health care overhaul, according to a forthcoming analysis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Re "The Health Care Sprawl" (Oct. 11):As a retired community newspaper editor in the Detroit region who covered suburban governments for 42 years, I have to add another perspective on how the media handles complicated topics for its readers.

headline.main: Letters: Fairness and the Health Care Sprawl
